title: Bioplarch: Starch Based Bioplastic As a Construction Material

author: Esen Gökçe Özdamar, Namik Kemal University (NKU)

segmentation: Hello everybody, first of all I want to thank all of you and especially organizers for inviting us to this conference and giving us the opportunity to share ideas with whites public here in Ljubljana.
Actually, this is the first presentation of our very new project.
And I'm going to make a presentation today about our project.
Its name is built large, combining bioplastic an architecture, and it's an interdisciplinary project that we have just started at.
Now.
Mickey Mouse University, Department of Architecture and the project is contract.
Conducted by me, I'm at, well, an R 30 year student Chairman, Chanter.
Can we have a new supervisor from Chemistry Department at our?
Institution.
Actually the project was dried when we moved to take your dog three years ago.
Take your dog is a very small waterfront city an it is located in the western neighborhood of Istanbul.
Actually it's very low, dense in population.
The city has about eight 800,000 people which is compared to Istanbul is very low when we compare because we actually lived in Istanbul before.
So when we moved to take your dog.
We were amazed by the potential of the city because the city is covered with sunflowers canola and also wet and the city's economy.
Depends on farming an industry as well in construction sector.
Here in the picture we can see canola plants.
Actually Canola takes its name from Canada.
It is an edible oil.
It's set to be one of the most healthy oil in the world.
But actually it is genetically modified.
So some people, some food experts put it in another.
Bye.
Yes, actually we were.
We were inspired by the potential of the city, but besides this reality there is an ongoing fact that there is an.
The city is left alone and there is not a environmental waste management.
So also there is water pollution as well and so actually there needs to be an urgent action taken.
By public and by managers of the city and the rate of death by cancer is rapidly rising due to the water pollution caused by the industry and construction sector.
Because of the fact the main factories of Turkey are located in a small district of this city.
First of all, we wanted to do something with the city because it was left very alone and because of the cities also political we use which is contradictory to the current government.
It's a bit leftist, so which is very much contradictory to what's going on now in Turkey.
So we need to take some action before the project we with our students.
Made a project and it is called.
It was called paper bridge.
We did it last year in the on the World Environment Day and we collect it with the help of the municipality.

We collected more than 15 thousands used paper cups from University accounting an from a shopping center and wash them and write them and then sampled and sold them to get into to form them into models and they were taken.
Into the city centre.
To make an arbitrary on sites pavilion, just it state.
For two or three hours, but this was at the just for public awareness.
That we have also.
Already.
Started again driving from this potential of this lonely city.
We we tried to work, we work in sorry we started working on our project by up large and we aimed within this project.

We aim to understand whether starch based bioplastics can be used as an architectural material, both interior interior design and is a facade material in construction sector and yet can it be degradable?
An eco friendly material and also our second aim is actually we have only one name but a second step.
We aim to understand whether against touch base by plastics can be an alternative to Simmons in concrete or replace degree similton architecture.

Concrete San provider metrics for carbon, glass and aramid fibers because we know that Simmons is not a very healthy product material in concrete, because in order to turn it in to put it into concrete you need to.
You need to consume too much energy and it's raises the carbon dioxide emissions so.
We try to aim to understand and find if we can find a solution to this to these aims.
Also, we want to experiment with the material where plastic material and it's like understanding between the material and the material.
So actually we don't want to direct the material and we are thinking and learning with the material.
So we put ourselves to the subject that we are focusing on.
When we look at, I just want to show some statistics but not go too much deeper into them as we look at the bioplastics statistics.
There's an ongoing crisis in the sector by also pack packaging, industry building construction, and the use of bioplastics is very common.
When we look at normal traditional plastics petroleum based plastics, about 29% of the package plastic use is used in packaging and 15% is used in building sector.
So because I actually.

Traditional plastics have been one of the most highly valued materials because of their extraordinary versatility and low-cost and their usage span a wide of applications from packaging to biomedical devices like prosthesis.
Also, building material, structural materials, transportation, electrical components and consumer products such as toys and also watches, cameras, etc.
But however, Despites span, use of plastics have become a significant concern due to the negative.
Effect on the environment and because they are largely non degradable which means that it takes millions of years for a traditional plastic.
Sorry petroleum based plastics to dissolve into nature and it is really harmful as the experts say.
So, um.
Yes, we can go further.

Plastic cups that we use, it's they're made of Poly, a Poly, lactic acid and drive from cornstarch.
The other example is plastic bags.
Another is what we are very familiar with.
Its 3D printing filaments are made of bioplastic startpage, startpage based plastics.

Another example, given from the shrimp shell, bioplastic, but it's not vegan and another can be.
Even as sellers attacked by a plastic package, this is a solid package.

Also, the Second World War interrupted the development of this car and since then the use of plastics in automobiles had been very common, but our plastics from renewable resources in use of in car got sidetracked actually.
Um?
Actually we chose potato is the main source of bioplastic because touch is one of the potential by by degradable polymers which can replace synthetic polymers for a limited time application.
Applications such as packaging and disposable cutlery, but as well it can be a construction material and also it is sustainable and very local.
It is produced in our city as well and it is among the one of one of the cheapest food that people can access.
Accord.
Into the flower.
It is Food and Agriculture industry organization of the United Nations.
But there is an ongoing rise in the production of potato in the world, but mainly in developing countries an and also it is one of the potatoes as well.
One of the most cheapest products, food that we can overcome hunger in the world.
So when we are working with food for the people, food for the animals and food for the soil as well, we have to be very careful.
To think about it, an in terms of holistic environmental and waste management.
So when you are producing with the food again, we have to be really.
Careful about it, so I want to show some of the projects that have inspired us.
One is mad at Millers Hofacker health like project.
It was an open site, artistic project and experimentation project.
Meredith designed Purus fans in a field in Michigan, Ann.
She experienced the decaying of the material and this is actually an edible by plastic made of starch.
So you can eat it, but there's no sugar.
Inside, but starch is already a sugar, so maybe you can even taste it.
Another inspiration is Marilla Valentis master thesis an she actually made her own starch from potato by peeling them, and then rendering blending them together.
An she made there should design A bridge.
Actually, this is a very successful material, now because she's, I think tasting it.
And this is again understanding the plasticity of the material have tensile it is.

And felt or rise or stone on different kinds of things materials.
And another interesting project is combining bioplastic again with Bloods.
It's on the left because we know that blood was some.

It is in Stuttgart.

We can see the relation to the building.
It is fire resistant space and these were about 90% of these facade is from renewable resources.
According to Stevens, who is the author of Bioplastics, Green Plastics books.

Careful about it and we use Apple vinegar.
